content: The iconic painting 'Starry Night' was created by which post-impressionist artist while he was staying in an asylum in France?

Ah, you're referring to the famous artwork "Starry Night." It was indeed painted by the renowned post-impressionist artist Vincent van Gogh. He created this masterpiece while he was residing at the Saint-Paul-de-Mausole asylum in Saint-Rémy-de-Provence, France, in 1889. Van Gogh had voluntarily admitted himself to this asylum after experiencing mental health struggles, during which he produced some of his most iconic works, including "Starry Night." This particular painting is known for its swirling skies, the prominent cypress tree, and the dreamlike quality of the village below, showcasing van Gogh's unique style and emotional expression through art.
